title: working from home mandatory matt hancock
story: The Health Secretary said he would consider changing the law to force employers to offer it to staff after the coronavirus pandemic.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAround half of the country has been working at home due to the outbreak, when Brits had to stay at home to help control the spread of the virus.And a study today said that nearly one in three people are prepared to keep working from home for the time-being.Speaking in a webchat with members of womens club AllBright this morning, Mr Hancock said the coronavirus pandemic had made flexible working the new norm and was something all good employers should accommodate moving forward.When askedhe would consider enforcing this through Government legislation, Mr Hancock replied yes, adding: The way you could look at it is theres a right to request flexible working.I definitely think it should be the norm where possible.We need to persuade people that allowing flexible working should continue. This is a change that is never going to go away.Mr Hancock also called for a study to be done into the efficacy of remote working, though he said the broader benefits of the practice - particularly for women - made it worth sustaining in the long-term.Theres a debate as to whether people work better when theyre working from home and its really dficult to know whether productivity goes up or down, but weve just had a massive experiment in that and we need to understand the answer to that, he said.Theres a big argument that productivity has gone up during this when people are working from home, certainly in terms of well-being.The main beneficiaries of home working were women as they tend to have more childcare responsibilities, he said, adding: Evidence showson average benefits women more than men.At the moment employers have to consider flexible working requests, such as job-sharing, working from home or ying hours.But theres no legal obligation for them to say yes.Officials at the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy department have now suggested making the right to work from home into law, Thereported last month.One Government minister told the publication: It makes complete sense.British businesses look set to be more flexible about working from home in the future – with nearly half of bosses believing it will save them money.Seven in  are now considering changing previous rules and regulations, after being so impressed with how staff have reacted.Three out of five people surveyed by Halax said they did not expect things to ever go back to normal.Many saw working from home as a way to be kinder to the environment, too.Many big employers have told their employees to work from home for the meantimethey can - some have been informed the changes will become semi-permanent for the next few months.Other offices are operating a hybrid system where some workers come in a couple of days a week, and work from home the rest of the time.Strict new rules are operating in workplaces, where there is a maximum capacity that can be in at any one time.Screens are put in place in some workplaces, and markers on the floor telling people to stay apart.The Government has said people who have to work in person at a site should do so.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. But there are  countries on the list which are open to visitors with no quarantine on arrival or for Brits when theyhome.Some have their own quarantine rules for visitors – or have closed their borders completely.Countries such as Australia and New Zealand have shut their borders and are thought unlikely to reopen them before Christmas because of the risk of importing the deadly bug.Vietnam has the lowest infection rate on the full air bridges list, while holiday destinations popular with Brits such as Fiji, Jamaica and the Bahamas are also very safe.Other hotspots like Greece and Cyprus also have relatively low levels of the deadly bug.Among the quarantine-free countries, San Marino has the highest number of coronavirus cases among its population in Europe at , per , people, followed by a rate of , in Andorra.In terms of popular European destinations for jet-setting Brits, Spain has  Covid- cases per , people Italy has  cases France has  Germany  Poland  and Croatia . By contrast, the UK currently has  coronavirus cases per , people.Meanwhile the UKs R value, which is the number of people each Covid- positive person goes on to infect, remains unchanged, sitting at between . and ..Greece is not accepting direct flights until July  while Cyprus, another popular holiday destination, closed to anyone who has spent the previous  days in the UK.Meanwhile Austria is advising that people only enter the country for essential reasons.In Barbados, people must produce a negative virus test less than  hours old or pay  to be tested on arrival. This would be the  and it should be constantly updated by Government.On Friday, the UK government changed its advice for Serbia, no longer allowing travellers towithout quarantining.There have been two nights of violent clashes in Serbian capital Belgrade by thousands of people protesting against coronavirus lockdown measures.Serbian authorities have reported  coronavirus deaths and , cases, but it has been claimed the data does not represent the full impact of the virus.Scotland has said it will continue to quarantine passengers from countries with a higher prevalence of Covid- than its own.It means people arriving in Scotland from Spain will still face quarantine rules.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: elon musk support kanye west presidential run 2
story: ELON Musk appears to be reconsidering his support for Kanye Wests presidential run amid fears the rapper is in the midst of a “serious bipolar episode”.The Tesla CEO gave the musician his “full support” when he declared his intention to join the  race for the White House last week.However, Kanye has since given a four hour interview to Forbes in which he supported anti-vaxx conspiracy theories and said Planned Parenthood carried out the “devils work.”Following the interview, PayPal co-founder Musk was asked on Twitterhe still supported West, to which he replied: “We may have more dferences of opinion than I anticipated.”Kanye told Forbes that he wanted the SpaceX mogul to head up Americas space programhe was to beat Joe Biden and sitting president Donald Trump.Yesterday, sources close to West told TMZ that he is in the midst of a manic episode caused by bipolar disorder – a condition which the musician has spoken openly about in the past.The report says the father-of-four usually has a serious bout “once a year”, and claims this is what has prompted his unconventional statements in the past week.His recent behaviour has left his family “worried” but they remain confident his condition will stabilize as it has in the past, the report claims.During a manic phase of bipolar disorder, a person may:www.NHS.ukSun Online could not immediately confirm TMZs claims.In , Kanye was hospitalised after a psychiatric emergency which forced him to cancel  concert dates.Last year, the rapper told David Letterman about his diagnosis and the paranoia he feels during a serious episode.He said: “When you’re in this state, you’re hyper-paranoid about everything.“Everyone - this is my experience, other people have dferent experiences - everyone now is an actor.“Everything’s a conspiracy. You feel the government is putting chips in your head. You feel you’re being recorded. You feel all these things.”In April last year, the musicians we Kim Kardashian admitted her husband wont take his medication - but says she knows how to handle his episodes.She told Vogue: “I think we’re in a pretty good place with it now.“It is an emotional process, for sure. Right now everything is really calm. But we can definitely feel episodes coming, and we know how to handle them.“For him, being on medication is not really an option, because it just changes who he is.Travelling a lot does set it off, so he doesn’t travel as much as he used to.GOT a story  EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus r rate up england 1 rising south
story: Across the whole of the UK, the Covid- reproduction number has remained stable since last week at . to ..⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut the latest regional statistics released today by the Government show it has crept up to between . and  in England after rising in the South.It comes almost a week after pubs, restaurants, hotels and hairdressers were allowed to reopen.The R rate has also risen above  in the South West where it is now at . to ., while the South East is . to .. East Anglia and the North West have also seen similar increases in their R value ranges - from . to . last week to . to . today.However, the value is down slightly in the Midlands - despite a local outbreak and subsequent lockdown in Leicester - from . to . last week to between . and ., this week.Experts say the true R rate probably lies somewhere between the upper and lower estimates - and the epidemic is continuing to shrink.Prof Oliver Johnson, of the University of Bristol, said: “The fact that R is still estimated to be below  across the UK implies that the epidemic is continuing to shrink overall.This is consistent with the numbers observed through positive tests and deaths, which both continue to decline.There is uncertainty on these estimates because R cannot be directly measured and inferring its value becomes hard when the number of cases is low.For this reason it is not possible to rule out the possibility that the epidemic is growing in some regions, though values in the middle of the ranges given are most likely.The figure gives an indication of whether or not the Covid- outbreak is growing. Above one, and its a sign the epidemic is spreading, while below one indicates an outbreak in decline.But critics of the R rate have pointed out it does not tell us how quickly an epidemic is changing.Thats why the Government introduced a new measure - the growth rate, which gives insight on the size and speed of change, whereas the R rate only gives information on the direction of change.The growth rate is currently - to two per cent, according to Sage.Neither measure is deemed better by the Government, but each provide information that is useful in monitoring the spread of disease.One thing to note is that as the number of infections fall, the measures do become less useful.Dr Yuliya Kyrychko, reader in mathematics at the University of Sussex, said: The growth rates have remained largely the same, but we have to be careful here.  As the number of confirmed cases becomes smaller, the estimates of the growth rate and the R number become more sensitive in a sense that even a relatively small local outbreak can have a major effect on increasing the R number.Prof James Naismith, director of the Rosalind Franklin Institute in Oxford, cautioned that the R value is not a particularly useful number.He said: What is now crucial is that the testing regime is sampling sufficiently to detect any local hot spots, that the inidual is supported to rapidly isolate, contacts are rapidly traced, rapidly tested andneeds be rapidly isolated.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.But Dr Kyrychko said while the R rate is important, it is crucial to have a detailed breakdown of cases at a local level, so community transmission can be quickly identied and contained.She warned with lockdown restrictions starting to ease it will take four to six weeks to see the full effect of more relaxed measures on the number of cases in each region.Its likely to be at least a few more weeks the impact of opening pubs and restaurants is reflected in the figures, she suggested.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: second pub seaside town shuts super spreader
story: The Somerset and Dorset pub in Burnham-on-Sea followed the Lighthouse Inn in closing its doors after one of its punters tested positive for coronavirus. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe Somerset and Dorset said anyone who has visited since Saturday needing to be tested will be contacted by NHS Track and Trace.In a Facebook post, the pub wrote: Due to information received regarding a customer testing positive for Covid- we are shutting, deep cleaning and getting tested.We are shut from tonight.The pub added it would be allowed to reopen once it has had a deep clean. It comes less than a week after one infected reveller spread the bug around the town.He was drinking at the Lighthouse Inn, one of several English pubs to have to shut after customers later tested positive.Also drinking in the Lighthouse Inn was an Indian restaurant delivery driver, whose bosses closed their premises when they got the news.Were you in any pubs on Saturday that have since closed  Phone    or email tips@the-sunIt is thought the drinker showed no symptoms and had been in the beer garden at the pub in Burnham-on-Sea, Somerset.It is unclear whether the Somerset and Dorsets closure is related to last Saturdays super spreader.The Sun Online has approached the pub for comment. Meanwhile, Health Secretary Matt Hancock praised " href"https:www.thesun news  which-pubs-closed-coronavirus-tests " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"pubs which had closed for public safety for “doing the right thing by their customers and by their communities”. He said: “This is NHS Test and Trace working precisely as intended. Three pubs shut so that others can be open.”The Lighthouse Inn had been open just two days before it was forced to close.Bosses at Saagar Indian, also in Burnham-on-Sea, said: “It saddens us to tell you all that due to unforeseen circumstances, we are closing Saagar Indian takeaway up until Friday.“This is because one of the drivers has been in the same pub as the person who has tested positive to " href"https:www.thesun topic coronavirus " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"Covid-.“This decision was not made easily. However during these tough times everybody’s health is the number one priority.”Nearby Vape Escape also shut its doors but later reopened after a thorough deep clean.And several boozers across the country have been forced to close after finding cases at their pubs. The Elm Cottage in Gainsborough revealed that one of its team members had developed mild symptoms.Bosses at the pub said on Friday they would stay shut this weekend as a precaution.Its owner, Leanne Underhill, said: “It wasn’t the re-opening we had planned. We were informed on Sunday that a customer who had visited us had tested positive.“All of our staff have been tested and have come back negative. All customers have been informed, in line with government guidance.“We have been following all the safety guidelines and, because we took the names and numbers of customers as they entered the bar, all have been contacted.”Lighthouse Inn manager Jess Green said: “The man who tested positive has done the right thing in informing the businesses that he attended so we can inform customers and get everyone tested.”Thousands of boozers in England reopened their doors on Saturday following months of lockdown.The Fox and Hounds, in Batley, West Yorks, and the Village Home, in Alverstoke, Hants, also closed following positive cases for the virus.A post on the Village Homes Facebook page said: On Sunday morning a member of staff was informed that someone in their family bubble had tested positive, they immediately went for a test. On Monday this test was confirmed as positive despite neither of them showing any symptoms.All other staff tested negative, but some remain in self isolation.Alog of all customers was kept and is now with Track and Trace PHE, the post added.Yesterday, the pubs landlord Robby Roberts told the BBC: A member of staff, one of my barmaids, has someone in her family bubble who has tested positive.All five staff who were on sht on Saturday have now been tested and we are waiting for the results.The pub is being deep cleaned and I have contacted the council. I am awaiting advice from them.He said she was working on Saturday when the pub opened for -and-a-half hours, with  customers visiting.Meanwhile, police in Durham closed the Number One Bar in Darlington and The Wheatsheaf pub in Chilton, County Durham, after officers decided drunk punters could not follow social distancing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris bbc license
story: The Prime Minister has called for the broadcaster to improve its quality of service after it vowed to go ahead with pulling the plugon free TV licences for over-s.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe BBC last year announced it would also pull the plug on the initiative from June , sparking a furious backlash.The scheme had been due to end on June  but the corporation extended the free leline for millions of elderly Brits due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which has seen many forced to stay at home.Speaking today, the PMs deputy spokesman said they were right to delay the move, but blasted the corporation for going ahead with it.He said: We have been clear we are bitterly disappointed by the BBCs decision not to extend the free licence fee beyond August.We dont believe that easing lockdown restrictions means older people value TV any less than they did a few weeks ago.The BBC must now look urgently to make sure how it uses its substantial licence fee income to deliver for people of all ages. The original decision had been met with widespread dismay with petitions calling for a U-turn attracting hundreds of thousands of signatures.It was rumoured that the freebie may be extended again until October but yesterday the BBC confirmed it would start to charge people from August .The Beeb claims the scheme would cost it £million to run, which in practice would have meant the closures of BBC Two, BBC Four, the BBC News channel, the BBC Scotland channel, BBC Radio  Live, and a number of local radio stations.BBC chairman, Sir David Clementi, said: “The decision to commence the new scheme in August has not been easy... The first to test positive was the husband, , who took himself the emergency room of the Canal Salat in Ciutadella with a fever on Monday.He tested and diagnosed soon afterwards. Another family member has been tested, but that came back negative.They are all isolated in the apartment where they are staying in Ciutadella on the west side of Menorca but are about to be transferred to bridge accommodation which might be one of the island hotels specically prepared to take positive coronavirus patients who dont need to be in hospital.Javier Arranz, spokesman for the autonomous committee on infectious diseases, confirmed the cases and said it is the first tourist outbreak in the Balearics.This outbreak in Menorca is the first of tourists, nationals, not foreigners, but despite that it is also a family outbreak, he told the islands newspapers.Despite the outbreak, Mr Arranz said that the epidemiological situation in the Balearic Islands is good.There are  active coronavirus cases on the islands and there has been one death in the last week.More than % are mild or asymptomatic cases, Mr Arranz said.From Monday, it will be compulsory for both locals and tourists to wear face masks in public places in the Balearics, but the coverings will not be needed on beaches or in swimming pools.Earlier today, another Spanish tourist region of Tudela in Nara was put on high alert after at least  guests at a wedding, including the bride and her mother, were struck down with coronavirus.The news comes after Spain recorded  coronavirus cases yesterday, the largest daily rise since May .There were outbreaks in Catalonia, Galicia and Aragon.Last week, health chiefs in the Balearic Islands warned sunseekers could be turned away from Majorca and Ibizatheres a big coronavirus outbreak. title: black passenger suing racism brussels airlines
story: American couple Ariel and Santana claim they were victims in the violent altercation - and claim the cabin crew had already become physical with them before the slap.Video of the incident was widely shared back in March in which Santana can be seen having an argument with the cabin manager on the Brussels Airlines flight from Ghana to Belgium.The row escalates when the stewardess slaps him after he allegedly spit on her, with Santana then striking her back.Santana and Ariel revealed they are planning on filing a lawsuit against the airline during an interview with YouTube account Bla Xit.The couple were travelling with their two children and Ariels mum - ing from the Ghanaian capital Accra after a trip helping with humanitarian projects on March .Ariel and Santana claim the clip only shows a small part of the story - alleging it was actually the cabin crew who were at fault.The row was sparked when the couple claim Ariels mum asked to move seats as a man sitting next to her kept elbowing her and leaning into her lap.Ariels mum, , then calls a steward who tells her he cannot help, sparking the couple to intevene - with Santana offering to take her place.The other passenger then allegedly started yelling at them in French as the situation escalated.The male steward seen in the video allegedly then struck Santana, leading to the furious row caught in the two minute clip.Santana - a former boxer - was arrested by police when the plane landed in Zaventem, before being released four hours later without charge.The couple are planning the legal action as they allege they are the victims of a racist attack on the flight.Ariel said: My husband and I were seated in a row with our two children. My mother was in the row behind us, between a man and a woman. But throughout the flight, they kept talking by disturbing my mother, banging her, literally leaning on her lap. It was hellish.After claiming the stewards didnt help, Santana then stepped in and claimed a steward then struck him the face without reason.It is here the couple claim the video picks up as he angrily argues with the cabin crew.Santana can be heard in the video telling the cabin manager he hit me as she attempts to calm down the situation. He then appears to yell in the womans face, she raises her hand appearing to wipe away spit - before slapping him.Santana responds by striking her across the face, with other crew and passengers left bundling him to the ground amid screams.Santana claims he was left with several broken ribs after the incident and the couple now plan to take legal action.He said he wants justice to be done. I have no other choice after what happened to me, reports " href"https:www.rtbf.be info societe detail_un-couple-d-afro-americains-va-porter-plainte-contre-brussels-airlines-apres-une-agression-raciste id" target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"RTBF.Santana added: I am a black man and in their minds it was: I do what I want. A steward can hit me, then a hostess. And that for them was completely normal.Santana also alleges he was manhandled by police upon landing, saying he told them he was struggling to breathe due to the pain in his ribs.He admits he was in the wrong to strike the woman, but claims he was pushed to the limit and was hit and jostled several times by the cabin crew.Santana added: Brussels Airlines cannot get away with this. title: poorer teens lower gcse a level grades under covid 19 exam system
story: The Education Select Committee said they have serious concerns the new system is unfair. While the appeals process favours the “well-heeled and sharp-elbowed”, they warned.They urged the exam watchdog Ofqual to do more to stop kids in Generation Covid seeing their grades hammered because of the pandemic.Students whose exams were scrapped because of the lockdown will be given grades based on coursework and teacher assessment.Ofqual will then standardise them to make sure schools dish out the same proportion of A grades as in previous years.But in a blistering report, MPs said the assessment system could lead to “inaccuracy and bias”.It could particularly hit poor and minority kids who often do better than their predicted results, the committee said.And they blasted the decision to only let pupils appeal their gradesthey can show discrimination or bias.Tory MP and committee chairman Robert Halfon fumed: “There is a risk it will lead to unfair bias and discrimination against already disadvantaged groups.“And we are far from convinced that the appeal system, which will be more important than ever this year, will be fair.“The appeals process seems to favour the well-heeled and sharp-elbowed.”He also warned that allowing every dferent exam board to run their own appeals system risks creating a “Wild West” of appeals.The committee urged Ofqual to beef up its appeals process to ensure it is “genuinely fair to all students”.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Her warning comes as she has been named to co-chair a  to review the World Health Organisationshandling of the coronavirus pandemic.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe former Prime Minister called for a dramatic increase in global action to save countries from collapse should the coronavirus pandemic get worse.The findings from her introspective investigation could take more than a year to publish, but Ms Clark is hopeful it will help mankind learn lessons from global outbreak.However, she warned the virus threat is likely to last for several years as a vaccine is still a long way off - potentially not arriving until late .Most scientists believe developing the inoculation is the only safe way le canto how it was before the pandemic.She said: Im told from Geneva that the most optimistic scenario for a widely available vaccine would be at least two and a half years.And even then we don’t know how efficacious it would be – it may not stop us getting it, it may simply mitigate the impact of getting it.In the end, a disease like this, like a plague of ancient times, will keep going as long as hosts present themselves for it, so we have to cut the transmission cycle.The warning counters some of the optimistic claims for the development of the first vaccines to counter Covid-.The Milken Institute is tracking at least  vaccine projects around the world - with British scientists hoping for a breakthrough by September.Ms Clark - who led New Zealand from  to  -will be working alongside former Liberian president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf to lead a WHO  investigating its own handling of the Covid- crisis.She called on the worlds nations to step up to help tackle the looming economic fallout of the pandemic.The former world leader said the world faces a .trillion crisis.She warned some nations would go over a clf with dire effects on their neighbours unless the G develops a joint response.She said: No-one has stepped up from the G to say we have to act even when it is not in anybodys interest to have one economy after another fall over.Ms Clark added: I think it can get worsethe G doesnt mobilise the support required for the international financial institutions to do their job.Britain is already feeling the pinch from the pandemic, with Chancellor Rishi Sunak confirming the economy has shrunk by  per cent in just two months.It come as the US formally notied WHO on Tuesday that it will be withdrawing from the UN body in .WHO has come under heavy criticism over the pandemic, with US President Donald Trumps alleging it was too China-centric.Ms Clark said: I feel in a sense that the coordination was left to rest on the WHO’s shoulders when it had spun out into a crisis that was far greater than the WHO could cope with.She described the task ahead as exceptionally challenging - title: rishi sunak breath fresh air love him
story: Can I, please, just take you away momentarily — oh most handsome of Chancellors — from your relentless schedule, trying to save our great country from calamity and collapse, to express my respect and astounding admiration for you It was asyou came from nowhere — one day bus driver’s son Sajid Javid was there and the next our screens were graced with the presence of what can only be described as possibly the most exquisitely beautul man I’ve ever seen .And I’m far from the only one who thinks so, what with you being voted our “hottest MP” in a recent poll.The country has been left swooning by your unparalleled generosity in the form of a £billion spending spree to save the economy.And that is why six in ten of us think you are doing a good job — the highest approval rating for any Chancellor since Gordon Brown in . All are tributes well deserved.Butyou’ll excuse the brief objectication, Rishi, I need you to know just how gorgeous you really are.Has there ever been a more perfect, excellent male face — chiselled and soft in one fell swoop. Your smooth, flawless, skin envelops your utterly geometrically-pleasing features.Your beam combines with what can only be described as the best set of gnashers in Whitehall. I will ease the burden of your economic battles in these unprecedented times and encourage your plans endlessly.I will mop your brow as you discuss with me the ision of labour, free trade and attempt to explain to me the laissez-faire economic system.I will listen to you as you read Adam Smith’s Theory Of Moral Sentiments at bedtime and we will laugh, together, at my inability to neatly peel a boiled egg.We both know you are PM material and I will be your biggest supporter and march the campaign trail showing nothing but awe, dedication and utter admiration.You were born to do this because you treat everyone with kindness and respect and you have the ability to make everyone feel part of your plan.Except for the people you just cannot help any further, but you will smile at them and make them feel blessed with warmth and love.Although it might be true to say we women often feel attraction towards a bad boy, age and maturity has made me see the error of my ways and I am now focused on this former head boy and Stanford scholar, who has only pure intentions in his heart. And very beautul hair.If you don’t mind me saying, I do believe you need a Viking in your le.As a blonde, blue-eyed Scandi, there is nothing more alluring than brown eyes and dark hair. Opposites attract, Rishi. You can’t deny that.When I mentioned in passing, on social media, that I might carry a torch for you, it turned out many of my followers do, too.Before I knew it, hundreds of women acknowledged their crush on Dishy Rishi.Many described how you make them go weak at the knees. One even threatened to fight me for you. I am not a violent person, Rishi, but I need you to know that I am familiar with handbags at ten paces. LOVE YOU, RISHI!”You don’t hear anyone hankering after that irritable and petulant baby Hancock. Few pine for that faltering Raab. And who would concede they brood over Boris But you — you are in a league of your own. You rise above the others in all your brilliance and glory.How on earth did we endure the likes of your predecessors — half-baked Hammond or dreary Darling No, you, my dear, are single-handedly bringing sexy back. title: i cant believe 747 is boeing boeing gone
story: I still marvel at it. And I still get a thrill when I find that the plane waiting at the airport gate has that distinctive roof bubble. It’s not my absolute favourite machine in the world but it’s certainly up there. Which is why I was sad to hear this week that, thanks to the ’s thirst for fuel, Boeing has pulled the plug.Back in the Sixties, everyone assumed the future of air travel would be glamorous and sexy and supersonic. That’s why Britain and France teamed up to make Concorde — which IS my absolute favourite machine in the world.But giant American airline Pan Am thought dferently. They wanted a plane which would carry lots of people cheaply, which meant it had to be big. So they went to Boeing and, in just  months — a staggering achievement — the  was born. It was not an easy birth. Pilots found in test flights that the wings would flutter.So, to solve the problem, engineers fitted ballast made from depleted uranium.There was also a problem with engines stalling for no obvious reason and an even bigger problem with the regulations, which said all passengers should be able to evacuate the cabin in less than  seconds.That’s just about possible when there are only  people on board but notthere are . Especially when  of them are up on the top deck.Still, they solved the issues at breakneck speed — by throwing people out and breaking their legs — and even though one of the first planes crashed into a post while landing and ripped off its undercarriage, the  went into production. And straight into another problem.A massive recession meant no airline was going to be daft enough to spend millions on one of the new behemoths, so in an -month period only two were sold. Both to Aer Lingus.Eventually, though, the  caught on and, soon, it became the only realistic way of giving yourself epic jet-lag.It was fast, too. Not as fast as Concorde, obviously. But when there’s a tail wind, pilots often have to ease back on the throttle of a  to stop it going through the sound barrier.And then there’s the safety record. Over the years a few have crashed but subsequent investigations have almost always found the plane wasn’t to blame. It was shot down, the pilot had been impatient or there had been a mistake with the servicing.Usually, though, the plane would survive. On flight UAL  from Los Angeles to Sydney in , the cargo door blew off, taking several square feet of fuselage with it.Nine passengers were sucked out and at least one went through the number three engine, which immediately broke.Shortly afterwards, flames began to appear from engine number four so the pilots, suffering from giddiness as the oxygen system had been knocked out by the explosive decompression, had to shut that down too. But despite all this, the plane landed safely and no further lives were lost.Over the years, the  has been militarised and turned into an airborne command-and-control centre for the US President. It’s been used as a fire engine, carrying , gallons of water to douse forest blazes. And it’s carried space shuttles on its back.But it’ll be remembered most of all for the joy it brought to the world, taking people to places they could never have visited before it came along. There’s no other plane like it. It even had a face like Thomas The Tank Engine. I shall miss it.GINA Prince-Blythewood, the female director of new action movie The Old Guard, says that “being able to throw a punch . . . is the biggest giveaway in an action film with women”.That’s presumably why she cast Charlize Theron in the lead role.Having seen Mad Max: Fury Road and, better still, Atomic Blonde, you get the sense thatyou bumped into the South African actress in a pub, you’d be very careful not to spill her pint.THERE have been queues round the block in London for a pair of limited-edition Air Jordan  OG Dior training shoes which cost, wait for it, £,.They are not made from gold or the foreskin of a rare whale. The laces are not studded with rubies and there is no platinum in the soles.They are just shoes.But somehow, it has been decided they should cost more than the very tidy  Mini Cooper I saw on Auto Trader this week.I NEEDED this week to set up an online presence for my new farm shop and, like every other old person, I called my daughter who popped round to help.In a blizzard of activity, she went online, bought something called a domain name, started a new email address, linked it to my phone, and then, by pressing and holding ious buttons, created an Instagram account. Throughout the whole process, she gave a running commentary, explaining what she was doing and why, and it was incredible.Because although I could tell she was speaking in English, I literally didn’t understand a single word she said.WHENEVER countries are asked to check their beaches for cleanliness, Britain always sends an army of boffins to the coast with test tubes and pipettes and some litmus paper.And having analysed the reports, we always say our beaches are filthy.Every other country, meanwhile, does no checking at all and says their beaches are fine.And I’m beginning to wonderthe same sort of thing is going on with the coronavirus figures. According to the latest numbers, there have been  Covid deaths in India for every one million people in the population. The number for Pakistan is , Turkey is , Egypt is  and Russia is . Whereas in Britain, it’s a whopping .This is seen as proof that we are the dirty man of the world, that we don’t wash our hands, that we cough all over one another and that our useless Government has done a terrible job.Or is it actually proof that we are the only country that’s counting properly TWO out of three people in Britain aged  to  think the Battle of Britain might be something to do with the English Civil War.So there’s a message for the BBC. If it’s serious about wooing younger audiences with something inspirational and educational, that shows -year-olds doing something truly heroic, how about clearing the schedules this weekend and showing the Battle Of Britain movie. I SEE it’s now possible to suffer from something called “unconscious racism”. This means you are being racist when you don’t think you’re being racist.So let’s just get this straight. I’m currently thinking about making a sandwich. I know there’s a bit of cold chicken in the fridge and I’m wondering whether to add some mayonnaise.This means I’m not thinking about robbing a bank. So, does that make me a bank robber GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: wayfair conspiracy theories child trafficking twitter reddit
story: One social media users Wayfair accusations about pricey storage cabinets took the internet by storm, similar to the refuted  conspiracy theory known as Pizzagate.The Wayfair conspiracy theory is the belief that very expensive cabinets listed for sale on the companys website were actually missing children.Is it possible Wayfair involved in Human trafficking with their WFX Utility collection  Or are these just extremely overpriced cabinets this makes me sick to my stomachits true, redditor PrincessPeach questioned on Thursday, according to Newsweek.Along with the redditors statement, a screenshot was shared from Wayfairs website, showing cabinets - with first names that social media users say happen to be of missing young girls.The cabinets pictures were named Neriah, Yaritza, Alyvia, and Samiyah - which social media users discovered to be the names of missing girls.Suspicions arose after the cabinet listings were removed off Wayfairs website - shortly after the posts became viral.The Wayfair conspiracy theories come a year after  Wayfair employees walked out of the companys Boston headquarters.The walkout took place after employees learned that Wayfair had profited off selling beds to detention centers holding migrant children.The overpriced cabinets ranged from ,. to ,..In a statement to Newsweek on Friday, a spokesperson for Wayfair said: There is, of course, no truth to these claims.The products in question are industrial grade cabinets that are accurately priced.Recognizing that the photos and descriptions provided by the supplier did not adequately explain the high price point.We have temporarily removed the products from site to rename them and to provide a more in-depth description and photos that accurately depict the product to clary the price point.In response to the sex-trafficking theory, one Reddit user said: Well how about the fact thatyou look up the SKU # of any of these products named after girls, you will see that the image results on any uncensored search engineshows images of children in bikinis. What do you make of that Despite a lot of social media users appearing to believe the theory, some Twitter users dont think its possible to ship a human inside of a box like the ones shown in the Wayfair photos.One person tweeted: Im pretty sure the US postal service or Fedex would hear a human inside of the box.. not to mention days or weeks in transit they would need food and water and a bathroom pretty positive you cant just order a human like that, but its still sketch that theyre ,+They were tweeting in response to another person saying: Can someone rich take one for the team and order one.Another person tweeted: “Hi. Just a friendly reminder that #Wayfair isn’t trending because the belief is that exploited children are being shipped in cabinets.It’s trending because the cabinetsmay be a front. Have a nice day.”NBC News reported Ben Collins also chimed in and slammed the conspiracy theory claims.Pizzagate QAnon people have Wayfair trending today. They ly claim price glitches on storage boxes prove that the company is trafficking children, Collins tweeted.This took off because of a post on Reddits r conspiracy subreddit yesterday, which is a clearinghouse for anonymous paranoia.The fictitious online conspiracy theory called Pizzagate spread online during Hillary Clintons unsuccessful run for presidency in .It claims that Clinton and her campaign chief ran a child sex ring out of the restaurant.The conspiracy theory originated on chan and was based on emails hacked from the Democratic Party and published by Wikileaks.It stated that Hillary Clinton and her former campaign manager, John Podesta, ran a child sex ring at Comet Ping Pong in Washington.The restaurants owner, James Alefantis, a Democratic Party donor, appears in the emails in relation to organizing a Democratic fundraiser.Users of chan and Reddit claimed that words in the emails - such as cheese and pizza - were code for young children and sex acts.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gordon ramsay mansion neighbour
story: The chef has already provoked fury with residents in the picturesque seaside village of Rock in Cornwall when he bulldozed and rebuilt the original beachfront home.The home, which has been on the market since April last year, has four bedrooms and private access to the Cornish coastline.But the Hell’s Kitchen star will soon have new neighbours - as an offer has gone in on the £. million beach house nearby.The gorgeous property has beautul views of the sea and boasts a private path leading straight to the beach.The garden and patio overlooks the sweary chef’s cubic super-modern pad.The contemporary beach house can be rented out as a holiday villa, or used as a second home.The high-spec bolthole has four bedrooms - three with en-suite bathrooms - and beautul views of the north Cornish coast.The home is in the area known as “Kensington-On-Sea,” where wealthy Londoners head to on holiday.The area is a favourite of Prince William and Harry, and Ramsay is one of a number of celebrities with houses in the area.Gordon Ramsay, his we Tana and their five children holed up in his multiple Cornish pads during the lockdown.However, the -year-old has been a controversial figure in the popular holiday region.The Michelin star chef was blasted by neighbours for moving down to Cornwall to his £ million home for the pandemic - as they were concerned he could have brought the virus.He was spotted travelling  miles back and forth from London to Cornwall.Ramsay was also roasted by the coastguard for flouting lockdown rules.The TV star had already enraged neighbours in Cornwall by flattening the s house he bought in  for £. million.The chef won an eight-month planning wrangle in  to knock down the old house and replace it with his mega holiday home, despite furious objections from nearby residents.Ramsay replaced the old house with an ultra-modern “Grand Designs” mansion, complete with two kitchens, a swimming pool, a wine cellar and four en suite bathrooms.There were  separate objections, with the fiercest critic another of Ramsay’s next-door neighbours.Tycoon Andrew Nisbet and his we Anne took exception to the planned annexe, claiming it would compromise their privacy.It is unknownRamsay’s long-running planning row affected the sale of the neighbouring house.The estate agent selling the contemporary property has boasted its privileged position with peaceful, beach views right in the centre of the village.It also wrote that the property is a perfect holiday home - full of spacious, airy living fit for any family.With views of the estuary, the two-floor accommodation would be a catch for any beach lovers who can afford the price tag. Ramsay also owns another £ million beach house nearby, which he bought to stay in while rebuilding the other home.The telly chef also rents out a luxury holiday home in Fowey for up to £,-a-week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sheffield united striker oli mcburnie
story: Sheffield United striker Oli McBurnie, , was due to go on trial but changed his plea at the last minute.He was arrested in October last year after cops spotted him driving at an idiotic speed in a mph zone.Prosecutor Philip Morris told the court: He came to the attention of the police at .am on October .He was first spotted in the Shell garage getting into the drivers side of a black Audi R.Officers noted that he drove off at speed. In fact, he drove off at considerable speed.There was a mph limit and he was grossly in excess of that.Police pulled him over and placed him in the back of a squad car and noted that he was chatty.Mr Morris added: He smelt of intoxicants and provided a positive roadside specimen.McBurnie, who earns £,-a-week, said he had stopped at the garage in Leeds, West Yorkshire to buy a female pal fags.He was taken to a nearby police station where he was found to have mg of alcohol in ml of breath. The legal limit is mg.McBurnie originally claimed he had only had one drink and denied the charge - insisting the police machine was faulty.But, flanked by his dad at Leeds Magistrates Court, he suddenly pleaded guilty.John Dye, mitigating, said: He had been drinking earlier and was with a female friend who asked for some cigarettes.He didnt even think about it at the time. He got in the vehicle and drove.Its real stupiditty on his behalf, not thinking straight and he apologises for that.Hes genuinely embarrassed for being here. He knows hes a role model to many people.Hes learnt a very valuable lesson.Mr Dye said that his club - who he signed for in a £million record deal - would probably fine him as well.Judge Michael Fanning told McBurnie: You chose to put others, including your passenger, at risk.He fined Scotland international McBurnie £, - the equivalent of  per cent of his weekly wage under new means-tested guidelines.He also banned him from driving for  months and ordered him to pay £ prosecution costs as well as a £ victim surcharge - bringing the total to £,.McBurnie declined to comment as he left court.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast storm sunny weekend storm edouard
story: Temperatures will reach mid s in the south of England on Sunday, as sunny skiesfor many places across the UK.This comes after showers hammered the country, as the remains of the tropical Storm Edouard moved across the Atlantic.The summer showers will take a break this weekend - bringing a brighter and sunnier end to the week. On Saturday, the south of England will see highs of C, while Scotland will see temperatures of up to C.Sunday will be warmer, with the UK reaching over C in most places.The Met Office told The Sun Online it is expected there will be wall to wall sunshine for much of Britain on Sunday.Met Office forecaster Becky Mitchell said things will be dry with sunny spells on Saturday with highs of C before the temperature then climbs.She said: Moving onto Sunday its wall-to-wall sunshine across the bulk of England and Wales, so blue skies and dry.Not a bad end to the week.Ms Mitchell said highs of C are expected for Sunday, before making way for potentially even warmer temperatures on Monday which could climb to C.However, she added the hot and dry weather across the southern part of the country may ease later in the week due to uncertainty from tropical cyclones in the Atlantic.Meanwhile, Met Office meteorologist Craig Snell also said Sunday will be the warmest day of the weekend.He said: On Sunday temperatures will be around C to C, and itll be warm especially towards the South East.Saturdays expected highs are between C and C.On Monday we may see temperatures of C to C in the far South East. It will warm up gradually as the week goes on, its not going to quickly shoot up.Generally the dry and sunny weather will persist over that period for most of England and Wales.With sunshine and high temperatures on Monday, Brits will likely be hitting beaches and parks once again making the most of eased lockdown restrictions.It comes after extraordinary scenes at the end of June when soaring temperatures of over C saw hundreds of thousands of people swarm to the seaside despite the pandemic.Downing Street had to issue a fresh lockdown warning - urging people obey the rules and continue to adhere to social distancing guidelines.Boris Johnsons spokesman warned further lockdown measures could be in placedthe rules are again ignored by Brits.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: Blame game begins as Tories wash hands of Covid complicityThey’re starting a well-rehearsed and well-trodden narrative they hope will get them off the hookShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  JUL NewsopinionConsummate thespians Blair and Johnson" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThat most gted of thespians, Tony Blair, never hesitated to wear a look of deep sincerity and apologise for Britain’s past. For example, its role in the slave trade, Bloody Sunday, the jailing of the Guildford Four and the potato famine of the s. But when it came to saying sorry for his own actions, like taking us into an illegal war in Iraq which killed  British service people and hundreds of thousands of locals, he couldn’t do it. The best the trained lawyer could come up with was to express “sorrow” and “regret” for any mistakes he had made. Boris Johnson is similar to Blair in many ways. He lacks any defined ­political ideology and is a ham actor who believes charm is man’s most powerful character trait. And he too has said sorry when there was little political capital to lose.Chasing the BAME vote at the last ­election, he apologised for the “hurt and offence” caused by Islamophobia in the Tory Party. And after approving an article in the Spectator magazine he was editing in , which claimed drunken ­Liverpool fans caused the  deaths at ­Hillsborough, he was forced up to the city by his party leader to apologise. But, like the man himself, it was insipid, insincere, and accepted by no one. Only in , when the Hillsborough Report demolished the article’s unfounded claims, did he offer an unreserved apology. And only after David Cameron, whose job the then London mayor coveted, had grovelled to the Hillsborough families from the Commons floor. An apology issued by Cameron because the blame game was up. More than  years after the Establishment, led by Margaret Thatcher, had accused fans of killing their own to sht guilt from itself, the truth had been established. And they had no option but to abide by it. Watching Labour leader Keir Starmer fail to elicit an apology from Johnson for blaming care workers for the appalling Covid death toll in their residential homes, I was hit with a nauseous sense of deja vu. Once again the blame game was kicking in. Johnson’s accusation that “too many care homes didn’t really follow procedures” was so deliberate and specic it had to have been crafted by Downing Street lawyers. They know an independent inquiry into Britain’s appalling Covid- death toll will conclude that confused government guidance, lack of testing and PPE, plus sending untested hospital patients back into care homes, were the main reasons , residents, % of all Covid deaths, perished between March and early June.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA former detective has told a public inquiry he was blocked from investigating child sexual abuse linked to politicians. Clive Driscoll was removed from the probe in Lambeth, South London, in , after naming prominent iniduals in a meeting with council staff. Mr Driscoll told the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse there had been a “concerted effort” by officials to stop him investigating. He said social services staff tried to steer him away from looking into the Angell Road home, which was run by paedophile John Carroll, despite the council knowing he had a record. They didn’t appear to have any right to be there.”  Referring to the work done by the Shirley Oaks Survivors Association, led by Raymond Stevenson and Lucia Hinton, he said: “How is it two people, Mr Stephenson and Ms Hinton, with a fraction of the resources [of the police], have put together  plus cases that have reached the evidential test of council lawyers and got £million paid out  “How has that happened when we [the Met Police] were the agency that should investigate .” The scale of the abuse in Lambeth has only come to light after SOSA was set up in . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe government overstated the number of Covid- tests it had carried out by , - and then quietly revised the figures, it has emerged.An investigation by Sky News showed that figures given during daily press briefings in April and May did not match the real figure.Now the Department for Health and Social Care has published figures showing a gap between the claim and the reality. A senior insider told Sky: We completely buffed the system. We said: forget the conventions, weaposre putting [this data] out. The Department has denied deliberately releasing misleading data, saying it is always looking to improve its statistics. It is reported that after an audit, it was found that the government figures did not add up, and new figures released by the Department reveal large discrepancies. On May , Sky reports, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the number of people tested had hit . million. However new data shows that just . million were tested in England by that time, rising to . million when Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland figures were added.  The data suggests that the number of tests was being overstated by , each week. The government has come under fire for the slow speed it increased the countryaposs testing capacity, with tens of thousands of Covid- cases thought to have been undiagnosed. In a letter to Mr Hancock, Sir David Norgrove, the chair of the UK Statistics Authority wrote last month that government figures were far from complete and comprehensible.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge introduced a group of schoolkids to her sporting hero  Sir Andy Murray during an exciting video call. While Kate is used to taking centre stage on royal engagements, she had to step aside on this one as the tennis mad youngsters couldnapost wait to grill the former Wimbledon champion on his career. In honour of the Wimbledon championships, which was scheduled to have its final this weekend, the duchess dropped in with a video call to pupils at Bond Primary School, quizzing them on their sports training before revealing she had her pal waiting on the line. Cheekily giving a handful of clues to leave children in no doubt as to who was coming, she told them: “Iaposve got a very important person here thataposs going to come and join us, that would love to meet you guys and might be able to share some tennis tips as well with you. Sir Andy, who would usually have been playing at Wimbledon this week, went on to answer questions from budding tennis players, disclosing he was missing big matches, friends and family, but passing the time with homeschooling and a new hobby of road cycling. Kate also turned interviewer during the chat, asking Sir Andy about his lockdown experience and whether he had kept up with training. He said he found the first five or six manageable, but then admitted he had “started to find it probably a bit harder to find things to do for the kids, to stay creative with ideas and games for them to enjoy. He said: “Weaposre doing the home schooling which is dficult. It was dficult but at times I really enjoyed it as well.” He revealed that he didnapost play tennis for about  weeks, taking up cycling instead to stay in shape. “I was going out on my road bike which was something I’ve never done before, so that’s something kind of new that I learned I enjoy during lockdown,” he said. “Itaposs quite important in these times to stay as active as you can because it good for the mind as well.”  Kate also askedhe missed big matches, to which he replied: “I think missing the big competitions, because Iaposm getting old for a tennis player - you never know how many opportunities youaposre going to have left to play the biggest competitions. “So missing Wimbledon this week is obviously a shame. “Iaposve missed the travelling...missing seeing friends like everyone . “Family, Iaposve not seen my mum and dad for a few months so iaposm looking forward to seeing them again hopefully very soon. “Thereaposs been some challenges but I guess sometimes when you go through dficult moments like this you learn to appreciate the things you maybe took for granted sometimes  “Iaposll definitely make sure I spend more time with my family and friends when I get the opportunity.” “Exactly,” the Duchess replied. “And hopefully that time is relatively near as well.” Kate made the aposroyal visitapos in her role as Patron of the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Clubfrom her Anmer Hall home in Norfolk to students from Bond Primary School in Mitcham ahead of what would have been the final weekend of the world famous tournament. The Duchess previously visited the school in January  to see the work of the Wimbledon Junior Tennis Initiative, the AELTC’s community tennis programme, which sees coaches deliver free tennis sessions to school children in the boroughs of Merton and Wandsworth. Appearing at the end of the children’s tennis lesson with AELTC Head Coach Dan Bloxham, the Duchess asked them about their time in lockdown and whether they have missed their friends, hearing about their new school regime of social bubbles.  One instructor said the children had been on fire in training that day, with the Duchess asking What sort of things have you been learning  Shown one of the drills, which involved young players running quickly on the spot, she said: Fantastic! Thataposs very important for your footwork isnapost it  Asking the classthey have missed doing physical exercise during lockdown she said: “Itaposs really hard isnapost it, to keep that self-motivation going. Itaposs very impressive youaposve kept that training going. Hearing about the best bits of watching Wimbledon, she added: “They [players] show great sportsmanship as well. I think tennis is brilliant for that, especially Wimbledon.”  Revealing Sir Andy to the class she teased: “Now, because youaposre all such keen tennis fans, Iaposve got a very important person here thataposs going to come and join us, that would love to meet you guys and might be able to share some tennis tips as well with you. “Iaposll give you a few clues and seeyou can guess who this special guest might be. So he ... is a he. He plays tennis for Great Britain. HEaposs a two-time Olympic champion. Heaposs a former World Number One... Can you possibly guess who this might be ” One boy piped up “Andy Murray”, followed by a round of applause as the former Wimbledon champion appeared on the screen.  The youngsters and coaches asked the grand slam winning tennis star why he picked tennis as a career, whether he remembered his first tennis match and comebacks from dficult times.  Sir Andy told them of the importance of having good family and friends around him to help “moving forward and working hard through setbacks. “The most important thing is to have fun,” he said.  “If youaposre enjoying it, you get more out of your lessons and your practising. Listen to your coach, that’s very important. Thataposs the two most important things at your age. “If you’re competing or playing any matches, try really hard in them. “But winning and losing isnapost the most important thing. Enjoying playing a sport and being active is the most important thing. “If you do go on to choose it as your career obviously the winning and losing changes a bit.” Asking the children about their other favourite sports, the Duchess and Sir Andy laughed as they animatedly shared their favourite football teams of Cha and Tottenham.

story: NewsMeghan Markle had ‘no intention of staying in UK and Harry has turned sourThe Duchess of Sussex reportedly always planned to leave Britain after marrying Prince Harry, despite spending £.m on refurbishing Frogmore Cottage, where they lived it has been claimedShareCommentsByJamie Hawkins:,  JUL NewsDespite spending £.m on Frogmore Cottage, Meghan Markle reportedly always planned to leave the UK " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Despite spending £.m of taxpayers on Frogmore Cottage, where the couple live, the Duchess of Sussex reportedly always wanted to leave Britain.The cash was spent renovating the Grade II-listed building after the couple married in . Frogmore Cottage was given to the royal pair by the Queen when they got married.But, according to royal photographer Arthur Edwards, Meghanaposs plan was always to leave the UK with Harry as soon as possible, The Sun reports.He told TalkRadio: All that house refurbishment at Frogmore and the money that they spent on that, she had no intention of staying here. He added: Unfortunately for the last couple of years, [Harry] has gone completely sour. He didnapost talk to me for a year, Iaposve been photographing him since he was born, and it was down to her. Meghan was understood to have chosen eco-friendly, toxin-free, vegan paint for the walls of the property. Five apartments were knocked together to re-form the cottage, while beams, floors and the water and gas systems were replaced. When they quit being full-time royals earlier this year, Harry vowed to repay the cash. Now it is believed the couple have agreed a “rental-plus” deal, above market rate, to keep Frogmore as their official UK base. The Queen made it clear they can use it indefinitely. The couple initially moved to Canada, but now live in Los Angeles, along with baby Archie. They are said to be living in a £ million mansion owned by actor and director Tyler Perry. The actor and director is reported to have given the royal couple the run of the expansive Tuscan-style villa. It boasts eight-bedrooms and  bathrooms, and was custom-built by Perry after he bought the -acre site back in . They are staying there with their son Archie and have already beefed up security there by erecting ft high screens around the back of the property. The couple have shared a few glimpses inside their new home on video calls as theyaposve done virtual engagements with charities and organisations during the pandemic.

story: NewsMirror giving away £, to help local heroes in virus-hit community projectsHere we turn the spotlight on just six of the worthy causes hoping to receive our help as the Mirror is giving away £, to lend a helping hand to local projects in conjunction with the Pride of Britain fundShareCommentsByVikki White:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsManager Lianne with Harmony the rescue horse at Hopefield Sanctuary " %, rgba, rgba, url"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThey are small ventures that are making a massive dference to their communities. And the Mirror is giving away £, to lend a helping hand to local projects in conjunction with the Pride of Britain fund. Fty organisations will get £, and  causes £, to help them adapt to a “new normal”. Entries are already pouring in from youth clubs, support groups, food and baby banks, local charities and many more. Here we turn the spotlight on just six of the worthy causes hoping to receive our help. Chat group here to help you relieve the suffering Mandy Burns has suffered with depression for most of her adult le. She is the secretary for Talk Tonight, a support group for anyone in need of mental health help. Mandy says: “Pre-Covid we would meet up on a Tuesday night and just chat. You could speak as much or as little as you wanted. “It took one lady months to tell her story and that was completely fine. Some people have been through tough times and it takes a good while to open up.” The group was set up last October in Selby, North Yorks, by Mandy’s colleague Paul and his we Aimee Rathbone. They have suffered with their mental health. Mandy adds: “More than  people turned up at that first group. Anybody can come along, evenyou’re just lonely. “It offers a routine and something to look forward to every week. The group went from strength to strength.” Talk Tonight is supporting members online until face-to-face meetings can resume. A grant would help to fund outdoor activity sessions for members. Tiny Hands Baby Bank Help for mums It’s been tough on mothers to find baby stuff A foster carer for eight years, Jane Robinson couldn’t find anywhere to donate baby items she no longer needed, giving her the idea for Tiny Hands. “My husband and I thoughtwe could get everything dropped at our house we could get it handed out in parcels for mums who were struggling,” she says. “The need was certainly there, we went from a little shed in my garden to a registered charity, almost overnight.” Tiny Hands has helped more than , families across Yorkshire in the past three years. Most referrals come from health professionals, including social workers and community midwives, who work with families in need of a cot, a pushchair or nappies and wipes to tide them over. Many mums are in horrendous situations, suffering from domestic violence or having been trafficked into the country. Referrals rose by % in lockdown but funding has been cut due to events being cancelled, leading to a lack of supplies. “Some have been unable to go out and get the stuff they need and we’ve had an awful lot of domestic violence referrals,” says Jane, of South Elmsall, West Yorks. Cherry Trees Respite care    Giving caring families time to recharge Cherry Trees provides a leline for more than  families a year who care for children with complex disabilities. The centre in Surrey offers short break respite care for up to  kids at a time, with families travelling from far and wide. Its head of fundraising Jane Hunnable, said: “We are supporting the child’s family, including siblings. They need time for rest and recuperation – in a lot of these families the parents will have   caring responsibilities and a little bit of respite goes a long way.” Children who stay have a whale of a time, with arts and crafts, sensory play, walks and trips to local attractions. “We pride ourselves on being a home from home,” said Jane. “We want every child who comes to us to have a great time, have fun and take steps like every other child does, to learn skills and grow and develop and flourish in le.” Cherry Trees, with a waiting list to attend, supported families during Covid. A grant would help to transform their garden which needs a complete overhaul. Jane added: “All children deserve the thrill of meaningful physical play and our new sensory garden space will create these experiences for them, regardless of their disability.” Hopefield Animal Sanctuary Winter will be a struggle this year From horses, cows, pigs, sheep and goats to rabbits and parrots, Hopefield cares for  animals in Brentwood, Essex. Some of the creatures are abused and neglected. Others, such as a pregnant donkey found tied to a lamppost in London, have been abandoned.  “Some people can no longer care for their pets because their circumstances change,” says the sanctuary’s general manager Lianne Angliss. “Others have bought an exotic pet and are completely out of their depths. The animals become malnourished or can’t be handled.” Covid- has had a devastating effect on Hopefield, which is usually open to visitors at this time of year. “Lockdown came in so we were unable to open at all in March,” says Lianne. “This year we’ve not been able to open at all and we’ve lost four months of fundraising. Winter will be a struggle this year.” Hopefield was put forward for a grant by Jenny Aldridge, who said: “I know the people who run it have been working day and night caring for the animals despite the current challenges.” Bede’s Helping Hands Food Bank    Tracy put her own cash in to feed the needy When the virus struck, Tracy Beaton had a way to go before her foodbank was ready.But with people more in need than ever she decided to open anyway, putting a lotof her own money into buying food.Donations began to come in from local businesses and supporters and Bede’s Helping Hands Food Bank in Jarrow, Tyne and Wear, was up and running.“I was in a fundraising group and noticed people struggling in our ward,” says Tracy. “The nearest foodbank was hard to get to. We get elderly folk, families who aren’t getting a wage, people who have just gone on Universal Credit and weren’t getting any money. If someone phones and they’re desperate, we will help.”Tracy calls elderly people in the morning from the foodbank’s HQ at the Bilton Hall Community Trust to askthey need a meal. “A lot of people I deal with are on their own. Some don’t want a meal but just a chat.“A grant would help us to continue. We are in desperate need of fresh fruit andveg to put in our packs – we don’t have the money to do this on a regular basis.”Alzheimer’s  Dementia Support Services    They’re a vital support network for many This charity in Northfleet, Kent, provides ious kinds of help for people living with the conditions and for their carers. It offers a -hour confidential dementia helpline, a day centre, a support at home service and a lot more besides. “They just do so much, including a special club for people under , a carers’ club and a buddies scheme,” says Jackie Thompson, who nominated the “vital support network”, which she used to volunteer at, for a grant. Some of the charity’s services went virtual during the pandemic and their minibus was used to reduce pressure on the NHS. But the specially adapted bus, used for discharging medically fit patients into the charity’s care at home service, was stolen and later found reduced to a burnt-out shell. Supporters soon began to donate cash for a new bus. Fundraiser Sheila Buckley says: “We have just been overwhelmed by the support we have had from the community.” Apply today for community cash boost

story: NewsDevastated familys tribute to sweet little rascal, , killed when car mounted kerbAs suspect has been named as the heartbroken family of cheeky, loving and soft-hearted Jack Worwood release a poignant tribute to the lad who was struck as he walked to meet friends in Ashton-in-Makerfield, near Wigan, to play football on TuesdayShareByKelly-Ann MillsLottie Gibbons:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsJack Worwood was rushed to hospital after being hit by a car " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe devastated family of a -year-old boy who died as he walked to meet his friends and play football have paid tribute to their sweet little rascal. Jack Worwood was hit by a car in Ashton-in-Makerfield, near Wigan on Tuesday, but despite being rushed to hospital he died the next day surrounded by his family. He had left home just  minutes before he was hit. In a statement, the family of Jack Marcus Worwood, , said: “You only had to meet Jack once, and you knew Jack. “He was a rascal, but a sweet little rascal - cheeky, loving and soft hearted. You could never be mad at him for long, as he’d soon have you laughing and kissing him again.  “He loved football, playing on his PlayStation and doing maths at school. He aspired to be an accountant and we knew he’d have done it, he was so bright. “He will be greatly missed by all his family and friends. He was such a character so adorable. “Love you so much Jack - from dad, step-mum Tracy, step-sister Caitlyn-Marie, mum, step-dad Lee and big brother Connor. “We are absolutely astonished by the amount of condolences we have had so far - truly blown away, and want to pass on our gratitude to you all.  “We would also kindly like to request some privacy at this very dficult time.” Liam Wilson, , of Livingstone Street, Ashton-in-Makerfield, has been charged with causing death by dangerous driving and assault by beating of an emergency worker. He was remanded in custody to appear before Wigan Magistrates Court today, the Liverpool Echo reports. A Greater Manchester Police spokeswoman said: At around .pm on Tuesday  July , police were called to reports of a collision between a car and a -year-old boy on Old Road, Ashton in Makerfield.  The boy, -year-old Jack Worwood, was taken to hospital with serious injuries, where, despite the best efforts of medical staff, he sadly died the next day. Jackaposs dad, Andrew Worwood, paid tribute to his son yesterday on Facebook. He said: Rest in peace my little man , you didnapost deserve this, Iaposm so so so so sorry, love you always and forever Jack. Fly with the angels, you will forever be a part of me and I will never ever forget you.  Jackaposs school, Hope Academy, said he was joyful and paid a loving tribute to him in a letter to parents and carers. Headteacher Mrs Adams wrote: We remember the funny, charismatic and joyful young man that was Jack. Staff and students hold so many wonderful memories. We will continue to share those memories with one another as we come to reflect on the le of such a special young man.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritainaposs top five cycling cities have been named as Cardf, Newcastle, Plymouth, Birmingham and London. A poll of , UK adults saw the Welsh city of Cardf triumph, getting a higher rating than any other city in the country, scoring an average of . out of five. Newcastle, which has picturesque routes stretching all the way from Gateshead Millennium Bridge to a number of locations, came second with a rating of . on average - a score also matched by the seaside city of Plymouth. Birmingham and London completed the top five, followed by Leeds, Edinburgh, Bristol, Glasgow and Norwich. Participants were asked to rate a range of factors including cycling infrastructure, such as cycle lanes and signage, local cycling facilities, countryside accessibility and their sense of personal safety when it comes to cycling in the city. The research, commissioned by routing planning and navigation , Komoot, also found more than one in  Brits have bought a bicycle since lockdown measures were introduced in March. And more than a tenth of bicycle owners have even learnt to cycle during this time, while one in four have borrowed a friendaposs bike or rented one in order to enjoy a two-wheeled ride. The bright schoolboy’s stabbing last March shocked the country. And as she saw the emotional toll of her brother’s death – and of the fight for justice after his killer was freed – on her shattered mum, Jade worried she might not make it through her self-isolation.Her fears tragically came true last month when Debbie Makki, , suddenly became ill and died, with suspected sepsis from an infection.Jade is convinced her mother would still be alive were it not for the weight of the grief and injustice, and believes she is the second victim of the violent act that claimed her younger brother. Jade says: “I did finally get to give her those hugs, on the hospital bed where she had died. “She was tested for corona and it came back negative, so they let us touch her. “I gave her a proper hug, the one I’d been wanting to give her for so long. “We were all still in shock, I couldn’t believe I’d lost her as well. “I think thatwe’d been able to give her those hugs while she was still alive, she’d still be with us today. “It was us, her children and grandchildren, who really kept her going through all this, just as she kept us going. “We couldn’t be there to comfort and reassure her during the stress and suffering she was going through.” When Debbie was laid to rest, even though Covid- rules meant only  people were able to attend her funeral, hundreds of neighbours lined the streets near her home in south Manchester, clapping as the hearse passed. Dozens of well-wishers stood at a safe distance outside the chapel at Southern Cemetery as Debbie was carried in, to the sound of Angel by Sarah McLachlan. Jade, , a former primary school teacher, says: “My mum had lived there for  years and the whole community really loved her.
